claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers a local type I interferon response, leading to broader antigen presentation.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3%
Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: The direct linkage between the interferon response and the broadened antigen presentation is an inference, though strongly supported by the data.

claims.claim: The vaccination-induced changes render tumors more susceptible to immune checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x

claims.caveat: This is a mechanistic claim primarily supported by preclinical models.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in human patients treated with ICIs.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A
The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: This is a retrospective, non-randomized finding and may be subject to confounding.

claims.claim: The combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 therapy leads to improved tumor control in mice.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.
ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.

claims.caveat: These are preclinical results in murine models, which may not fully translate to human cancers.
